POP.title: Total Population
POP.description: The total population of the selected blockgroup.
POP.importance: Total population indicates the number of people living in a selected area. It is used to calculate density, and other per capita data. Trends of population increase or decrease can help the City, County and other service providers know where infrastructure and other services may be needed.
POP.tech_notes: This data is from the 2010 Decennial Census. The Neighborhood Compass will report 100% population counts from the 2010 Decennial Census until population estimates for blockgroups are available through the American Community Survey (ACS) for 2010-2014. Annual population updates will then be made from the ACS until the 2020 Decennial Census.
POP.links:
Durham City/County Comprehensive Plan
North Carolina Population Projections
Decennial Census 2010

POPDENS.title: Population Density
POPDENS.description: The density of population within the selected blockgroup.
POPDENS.importance: Population density indicates the number of people living in a selected boundary divided by the area (in square miles) of the boundary. Density of population helps the City, County and other service providers know where infrastructure and other services are used most. Businesses might use population density to understand where markets exist for goods and services.
POPDENS.tech_notes: This measurement provides the population per square mile based on the 2010 Census using blockgroups. The Neighborhood Compass will report 100% population counts from the 2010 Decennial Census until population estimates for blockgroups are available through the American Community Survey (ACS) for 2010-2014. Annual population updates will then be made from the ACS until the 2020 Decennial Census.
POPDENS.links:
Durham City/County Comprehensive Plan
City of Durham
Durham County
Durham City-County Planning
Triangle J Council of Governments
Decennial Census 2010

PCTLATINO.title: Latino or Hispanic
PCTLATINO.description: The percentage of the blockgroup population that is Latino or Hispanic.
PCTLATINO.importance: Information on race is required for many Federal programs and is critical in making policy decisions, particularly for civil rights. States use these data to meet legislative redistricting principles. Race data also are used to promote equal employment opportunities and to assess racial disparities in health and environmental risks.
PCTLATINO.tech_notes: The percent of the total population reporting their ethnicity to be Latino or Hispanic. Ethnicity is a separate characteristic from race and individuals reporting their ethnicity to be Latino or Hispanic may also report a race description such as White or African American.

PCTWH_NL.title: White or Caucasian
PCTWH_NL.description: The percentage of the blockgroup population that is White or Caucasian.
PCTWH_NL.importance: Information on race is required for many Federal programs and is critical in making policy decisions, particularly for civil rights. States use these data to meet legislative redistricting principles. Race data also are used to promote equal employment opportunities and to assess racial disparities in health and environmental risks.
PCTWH_NL.tech_notes: The percent of the total population reporting their race to be White and ethnicity as not Latino or Hispanic. Ethnicity is a separate characteristic from race and individuals reporting their ethnicity to be Latino or Hispanic may also report a race description such as White or African American.

PCTBLK_NL.title: Black or African American
PCTBLK_NL.description: The percentage of the blockgroup population that is Black or African American.
PCTBLK_NL.importance: Information on race is required for many Federal programs and is critical in making policy decisions, particularly for civil rights. States use these data to meet legislative redistricting principles. Race data also are used to promote equal employment opportunities and to assess racial disparities in health and environmental risks.
PCTBLK_NL.tech_notes: The percent of the total population reporting their race to be Black or African American and ethnicity as not Latino or Hispanic. Ethnicity is a separate characteristic from race and individuals reporting their ethnicity to be Latino or Hispanic may also report a race description such as White or African American.

PCTASIANNL.title: Asian
PCTASIANNL.description: The percentage of the blockgroup population that is Asian.
PCTASIANNL.importance: Information on race is required for many Federal programs and is critical in making policy decisions, particularly for civil rights. States use these data to meet legislative redistricting principles. Race data also are used to promote equal employment opportunities and to assess racial disparities in health and environmental risks.
PCTASIANNL.tech_notes: The percent of the total population reporting their race to be Asian and ethnicity as not Latino or Hispanic. Ethnicity is a separate characteristic from race and individuals reporting their ethnicity to be Latino or Hispanic may also report a race description such as White or African American.

PCTOTHERNL.title: Other Race
PCTOTHERNL.description: The percentage of the blockgroup population that report Other or Multiple Race categories.
PCTOTHERNL.importance: Information on race is required for many Federal programs and is critical in making policy decisions, particularly for civil rights. States use these data to meet legislative redistricting principles. Race data also are used to promote equal employment opportunities and to assess racial disparities in health and environmental risks.
PCTOTHERNL.tech_notes: The percent of the total population reporting their race to be American Indian, Other Race, Multiple Race and their ethnicity as not Latino or Hispanic. Ethnicity is a separate characteristic from race and individuals reporting their ethnicity to be Latino or Hispanic may also report a race description such as White or African American.

RE_DIVERSE.title: Racial & Ethnic Diversity
RE_DIVERSE.description: The degree of race and ethnicity diversity in the selected geography.
RE_DIVERSE.importance: Diversity is a deeply valued component of our community, reflecting our mutual human rights and values, and equal access to opportunity for people of all races and ethnicities. Research on race and ethnic diversity has shown that it influences social solidarity, social trust, and tolerance among other aspects of community life.
RE_DIVERSE.tech_notes: A higher number in this measure reflects both a higher number of race and ethnicity categories present and more people of each race and ethnicity. A diversity measurement of 100 would mean all major race and ethnicity categories are present and equally represented, while a measure of 0 would indicate only one race or ethnicity is present. The calculation of this measurement uses the Simpson Index of Diversity.
RE_DIVERSE.source: U.S. Decennial Census, 2010; Neighborhood Improvement Services 2013

MEDAGE.title: Median Age
MEDAGE.description: The median age for the selected blockgroup.
MEDAGE.importance: The median age is used to indicate the age of the population in general. Communities with higher numbers of aging residents may face different challenges than others and might require enhanced services or physical infrastructure.
MEDAGE.tech_notes:
The age at the midpoint of the population. Half of the population is older than this age, and half is younger.
As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.

PctUnd18.title: Youth Population
PctUnd18.description: The percent of the total population under 18 years of age.
PctUnd18.importance: This measurement indicates the total youth population of an area. Higher concentrations of school-age children can reflect greater need for youth-specific programming, community recreation facilities and other opportunities for skill and occupational development.
PctUnd18.tech_notes: The percent of population under 18 years of age is calculated using the same Decennial Census counts of population as those used for total population, population density, and race and ethnicity. The population under 18 years of age is divided by the total population for each blockgroup.

Pct65Up.title: Retirement-Age Population
Pct65Up.description: The percent of the total population 65 years of age and up.
Pct65Up.importance: This measurement indicates the total 65 and-up population of an area. Higher concentrations of aging adults can reflect a greater need for supportive programming, accessible public and private facilities, and proximity to core needs and services.
Pct65Up.tech_notes: The percent of population 65 years of age and older is calculated using the same Decennial Census counts of population as those used for total population, population density, and race and ethnicity. The population 65 years and older is divided by the total population for each blockgroup.

PCTST2BASE.title: Students Attending Base School
PCTST2BASE.description: The percent of Durham Public Schools students in each neighborhood who attend their local community school.
PCTST2BASE.importance: Durham Public Schools offers significant options in school choice.  Families can choose their community school or apply to schools with specific themes.  Transportation is typically available for all options but can vary in time and distance.  This data reveals how frequently families choose each option.
PCTST2BASE.tech_notes: The percent of students attending base schools is derived from the number of base school attendees divided by total Durham Public School students. This does not include students attending private or charter schools.

PCTES2BASE.title: Students Attending Base School: Grade 5 and Below
PCTES2BASE.description: The percent of Durham Public Schools students in each neighborhood who attend their local community school.
PCTES2BASE.importance: Durham Public Schools offers significant options in school choice.  Families can choose their community school or apply to schools with specific themes.  Transportation is typically available for all options but can vary in time and distance.  This data reveals how frequently families choose each option.
PCTES2BASE.tech_notes: The percent of students attending base schools is derived from the number of base school attendees divided by total Durham Public School students. This does not include students attending private or charter schools.
PCTES2BASE.links:
Durham Public Schools Student Assignment
DPS Elementary Attendance and Movement

PCTMS2BASE.title: Students Attending Base School: Grades 6 to 8
PCTMS2BASE.description: The percent of Durham Public Schools students in each neighborhood who attend their local community school.
PCTMS2BASE.importance: Durham Public Schools offers significant options in school choice.  Families can choose their community school or apply to schools with specific themes.  Transportation is typically available for all options but can vary in time and distance.  This data reveals how frequently families choose each option.
PCTMS2BASE.tech_notes: The percent of students attending base schools is derived from the number of base school attendees divided by total Durham Public School students. This does not include students attending private or charter schools.

PCTHS2BASE.title: Students Attending Base School: Grades 9 to 12
PCTHS2BASE.description: The percent of Durham Public Schools students in each neighborhood who attend their local community school.
PCTHS2BASE.importance: Durham Public Schools offers significant options in school choice.  Families can choose their community school or apply to schools with specific themes.  Transportation is typically available for all options but can vary in time and distance.  This data reveals how frequently families choose each option.
PCTHS2BASE.tech_notes: The percent of students attending base schools is derived from the number of base school attendees divided by total Durham Public School students. This does not include students attending private or charter schools.

PCTR_BUSST.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Bus Stops
PCTR_BUSST.description: The percent of households that are within one quarter-mile of DATA and Triangle Transit bus stops.
PCTR_BUSST.importance: Household proximity to public transit indicates transportation options for those with cars and indicates access to regional transportation for those without cars. This measurement is one of three included in the Compass that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (daily and nightly bus arrivals are the other two).
PCTR_BUSST.tech_notes: Households include all residential units, not just residential parcels. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies. Bus stop locations used in this calculation are those active from January 1 to July 1 of 2013.
PCTR_BUSST.links:
Triangle Transit
Durham Area Transit Authority

DAYTRIPS.title: Total Daily Bus Arrivals
DAYTRIPS.description: The count of daytime bus arrivals for all routes in the selected blockgroup.
DAYTRIPS.importance: This measurement is one of three included in the Compass that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (nightly bus arrivals and households within a quarter mile of transit stops are the other two).
DAYTRIPS.tech_notes: Bus routes used in this calculation are those active as of August 28, 2013 and do not serve all areas of Durham County. Click here for a map of the Triangle Transit service area and here for a map of DATA's service area.
DAYTRIPS.links:
Triangle Transit
Durham Area Transit Authority

EVETRIPS.title: Total Nightly Bus Arrivals
EVETRIPS.description: The count of nighttime bus arrivals for all routes in the selected blockgroup.
EVETRIPS.importance: This measurement is one of three that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (daily bus arrivals and households within a quarter mile of transit stops are the other two).
EVETRIPS.tech_notes: Bus routes used in this calculation are those active as of August 28, 2013 and do not serve all areas of Durham County. Click here for a map of the Triangle Transit service area and here for a map of DATA's service area.
EVETRIPS.links:
Triangle Transit
Durham Area Transit Authority

PCTR_BANK.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Banks
PCTR_BANK.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of a commercial bank or credit union.
PCTR_BANK.importance: Banking is a core community service, providing financial planning, savings, and management services to households. Neighborhoods without easy access to such core services are transportation dependent for primary needs, leading to higher costs of living and reliance on inadequate convenience services.
PCTR_BANK.tech_notes: This measurement includes both commercial bank locations and credit unions. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes 52211 and 52213. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
PCTR_BANK.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2013)

PCTR_GRCR.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Full Service Grocers
PCTR_GRCR.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of full-service grocery stores.
PCTR_GRCR.importance: Grocery stores are among the core services a community needs, providing reliable access to basic foods: dry goods, meat, fresh produce, and dairy. Neighborhoods without easy access to grocers are transportation-dependent for core needs, leading to higher costs of living and reliance on inadequate convenience food sources.
PCTR_GRCR.tech_notes: Grocery stores include chain groceries and independent full-service stores. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code 44511. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
PCTR_GRCR.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2013)
PCTR_GRCR.links:
Urban Ministries of Durham
Food Bank of Central & Eastern North Carolina
Durham County Food Pantries

PCTR_PHARM.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Pharmacies
PCTR_PHARM.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of pharmacies.
PCTR_PHARM.importance: Pharmacies are among the core services a community needs. They allow access to prescriptions and basic household pharmaceuticals, medical devices and preventative care products. In addition, many pharmacies offer 'minute-clinics' for basic primary care services.
PCTR_PHARM.tech_notes: Pharmacies include traditional storefront locations of independent and chain drug stores, as well as big-box retail locations. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code 44611. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
PCTR_PHARM.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2013)
PCTR_PHARM.links:
Senior PharmAssist
Durham County Health Department

PCTWRKHM.title: Working from Home
PCTWRKHM.description: The percentage of workers who report their primary workplace to be their home.
PCTWRKHM.importance: This measurement includes persons telecommuting to employment based in locations elsewhere, in addition to those with other home-based occupations. The transportation impacts of increased home-based employment can be significant in terms of reduced vehicle miles traveled, congestion, and travel demand.
PCTWRKHM.tech_notes: As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this ACS product are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTWRKHM.links:
GoTriangle - Telework
Transportation Implications of Telecommuting, US DOT
American Community Survey

PCTBIKEWK.title: Commuting to Work by Bicycle
PCTBIKEWK.description: The percentage of workers commuting to work by bicycle.
PCTBIKEWK.importance: This measurement indicates the proportion of residents who ride bicycles to work in each area, but it also implies a certain degree of proximity to workplaces. In addition, it may reflect the perceived safety of biking in each selected area and lower household access to cars or public transit.
PCTBIKEWK.tech_notes: As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTBIKEWK.links:
Durham Bike Map (Mobile)
Bike Durham
Durham Bicycle and Pedestrian Advisory Commission (BPAC)
American Community Survey

PCTWLKWK.title: Commuting to Work by Foot
PCTWLKWK.description: The percentage of workers commuting to work by foot.
PCTWLKWK.importance: A higher number of residents walking to work reflects residential proximity to employers, a safe pedestrian network, and/or a preference or necessity to walk. Walking has health and financial benefits, but as an alternative to driving it offers many of the same environmental and infrastructural benefits as biking or working from home: reduced vehicle miles traveled, reduced congestion, and reduced travel demand.
PCTWLKWK.tech_notes: As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this ACS product are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTWLKWK.links:
Durham Bicycle and Pedestrian Advisory Commission (BPAC)
Durham Bike Map (Mobile)
American Community Survey

SWTORD.title: Sidewalk-to-Roadway Ratio
SWTORD.description: The ratio of sidewalk length to road length in the selected area.
SWTORD.importance: This ratio indicates how well-served an area is by sidewalks. The ratio is to be read as the number of sidewalk feet for every hundred feet of roadway in a neighborhood. If the number is more than 100, it is likely due to sidewalks existing on both sides of many neighborhood streets.
SWTORD.tech_notes: The intention of this measurement is to indicate how well neighborhood roads serve pedestrians. Pedestrian or bike paths not adjacent to roadways are not among the sidewalks counted here. Areas reporting 'N/A' are outside City limits and do not contain annexed communities - the City does not maintain or build sidewalks in those areas.
SWTORD.links:
2013 Sidewalk Repairs and Curb Ramps (SW-29)
City-Maintained Streets

LUDIVERSE.title: Land Use Diversity
LUDIVERSE.description: The indexed value of diversity of land uses in these categories: agriculture, residential, commercial, recreation, industrial, community services, public services (utilities), wild and forested lands.
LUDIVERSE.importance: The diversity of land uses can reflect the richness of social and economic life in a community. Just as mixed uses in a single property are desirable for bringing people and their service or amenity needs closer to one another, the same is true within neighborhoods. Land use diversity can have transportation, health and environmental associations as well as create greater collocation of jobs and housing.
LUDIVERSE.tech_notes: A higher value in this measure reflects both a higher number of land use categories present and more properties in each category. A measure of 100 would mean each of the possible types of land use is present and that there is an equal number of each. A measure of 0 would mean only one type is present. The calculation of this measurement uses the Simpson Index of Diversity.
LUDIVERSE.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services and Durham County Tax Administration (2013)
LUDIVERSE.links:
The Measurement of the Level of Mixed Land Uses: A Synthetic Approach
Durham City-County Planning Department

MHI.title: Median Household Income
MHI.description: Median household income for the selected blockgroup.
MHI.importance: The median household income provides an indication of how well people are doing financially in a neighborhood. Lower wage earners may have higher percentages of their income devoted to consumption and less for saving, making them less resilient in economic downturns. Higher wage earners may have more of their income available for consumption and more savings that can enable them to be more resilient in economic downturns. Service providers and retailers look at income levels to help them locate their services.
MHI.tech_notes:
The household income at the midpoint of all households. Half of the households in this blockgroup earn a higher annual income and half earn a lower annual income. These amounts are inflation-adjusted for 2011.
As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
MHI.links:
Durham City/County Comprehensive Plan
City of Durham
Durham County
American Community Survey

PCI.title: Per Capita Income
PCI.description: Per capita income for individuals in the selected blockgroup.
PCI.importance: Per capita income is a reflection of the comparative income of individuals, rather than households. While it is still a reflection of the economic resiliency of a neighborhood it is also influenced by the types of occupations residents pursue, whether they work full- or part-time, and local unemployment rates.
PCI.tech_notes:
Average obtained by dividing aggregate income by total population of an area. These amounts are inflation-adjusted for 2011.
As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCI.links:
Durham City/County Comprehensive Plan
City of Durham
Durham County
American Community Survey

RVALPSM_12.title: Residential Building Permit Values
RVALPSM_12.description: The value per square mile of residential building permits filed during the 2012 calendar year.
RVALPSM_12.importance: Residential building permit values reflect active investment in property, whether improvements or maintenance for existing residences or development of new homes.
RVALPSM_12.tech_notes: The value of residential building permits for each boundary divided by the area (in square miles) of each. These permits include new construction as well as renovations and exclude demolitions.
RVALPSM_12.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker
Durham Community Development Department

CVALPSM_12.title: Commercial Building Permit Values
CVALPSM_12.description: The value per square mile of commercial building permits filed during the 2012 calendar year.
CVALPSM_12.importance: Commercial building permit values reflect active investment in property, whether improvements to or maintenance of existing properties or development of new commercial properties.
CVALPSM_12.tech_notes: The value of commercial, business, and industrial building permits for each boundary divided by the area (in square miles) of each. These permits include new construction as well as renovations and exclude demolitions.
CVALPSM_12.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker

PCTSSI.title: Supplemental Security Income
PCTSSI.description: The percent of households receiving Supplemental Security Income.
PCTSSI.importance: Supplemental Security Income (SSI) is a nationwide U.S. assistance program administered by the Social Security Administration that guarantees a minimum level of income for aged, blind, or disabled individuals.
PCTSSI.tech_notes: As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this ACS product are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTSSI.links:
US Social Security Administration
American Community Survey
Census Bureau Data Dictionary

PCTRENT.title: Renter-Occupied Housing
PCTRENT.description: The percentage of housing in the selected blockgroup that is renter-occupied.
PCTRENT.importance: Higher percentages of rental units in a blockgroup may indicate an increased need for certain services, such as proactive rental inspection (PRIP). Combined with gross rent as a percentage of household income, the percent of renter-occupied units can help determine where affordable housing programming can be effective.
PCTRENT.tech_notes:
All occupied units which are not owner occupied, whether they are rented for cash rent or occupied without payment of cash rent, are classified as renter-occupied. Renter-occupied status also applies to units in continuing care arrangements, such as assisted living.
As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTRENT.links:
City of Durham Community Development
City of Durham Human Relations (Fair Housing)
Durham Housing Authority
Durham City/County Comprehensive Plan
American Community Survey
Census Bureau Data Dictionary

PCTUNFRENT.title: Gross Rent Over 30% of Income
PCTUNFRENT.description: The percent of renters spending 30% or more of their monthly income on housing and housing-related costs.
PCTUNFRENT.importance: 30 percent of monthly or annual household income is widely regarded as the standard beyond which housing is unaffordable. This measure reflects the comparative affordability of rental housing in Durham blockgroups. While this is a stand-alone measurement the cost of daily household transportation has a dynamic relationship with housing location and should also be considered a component of housing affordability.
PCTUNFRENT.tech_notes:
Gross rent as a percentage of household income is a computed ratio of monthly gross rent to monthly household income.
As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTUNFRENT.links:
Habitat Durham
Reinvestment Partners
City of Durham Human Relations (Fair Housing)
Durham Housing Authority
DurhamCares
American Community Survey

PCTUNFOWN.title: Housing Ownership Costs 30% or More
PCTUNFOWN.description: The percent of owner-occupied units that cost owners 30% or more of their monthly income.
PCTUNFOWN.importance: This measurement is related to home owners with mortgages. While home owners with no mortgage generally have lower housing related costs, those with mortgages may have very high housing costs that compare with or even exceed rental costs.
PCTUNFOWN.tech_notes:
This includes selected monthly ownership costs such as mortgage or similar debts, taxes, insurance, utilities, and condo or homeowners fees.
As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTUNFOWN.links:
Habitat Durham
Reinvestment Partners
American Community Survey
Census Bureau Data Dictionary

R_AVGYR.title: Average Year of Residential Construction
R_AVGYR.description: The average year built of all types of residential construction.
R_AVGYR.importance: The age of housing generally reflects the development history of the city - Durham's oldest neighborhoods have average residential construction years in the 1920s and 30s. This measure can also indicate greater maintenance needs for a community's housing stock. If a community has a concentration of building code violations and aging housing it may warrant focused efforts in repairing, restoring, and preserving housing.
R_AVGYR.tech_notes: The average age of all residential units - including single-family, multi-family, townhouse and all other residential categories.
R_AVGYR.links:
City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services
City of Durham Community Development
Preservation Durham
Open Durham

RCODEV_12.title: Minimum Housing Code Violations
RCODEV_12.description: Minimum housing code violations per 100 dwelling units.
RCODEV_12.importance: Violations of the City minimum housing code can interfere with the safety and quality of life of residents and can have a negative impact on surrounding homes and properties. The City of Durham minimum housing standards code is enforced by the Neighborhood Improvement Services department.
RCODEV_12.tech_notes: The number of minimum housing code violations divided by the estimated dwelling unit count, multiplied by 100. This measurement includes all minimum housing code violations, excluding calls found to be not in violation. This does include orders to repair, demolish, unsafe structures, and boarded properties. NOTE: These numbers may be higher in areas where the City's Proactive Rental Inspection Program (PRIP) is active. For a map of these areas, please refer to the PRIP link in Additional Resources. Because minimum housing code is enforced by the City of Durham but not outside the city in Durham County, this measurement reflects a City-only service and parts of Durham County are not represented by this data. Dwelling unit estimates for this measure therefore only count those within the City administrative boundary.
RCODEV_12.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services (2012)
RCODEV_12.links:
Proactive Rental Inspection Program
Durham One Call
North Carolina Minimum Housing Code
Neighborhood Improvement Services

WCODEV_12.title: Unmaintained Property Violations
WCODEV_12.description: Unmaintained property violations per 100 dwelling units.
WCODEV_12.importance: Unmaintained properties can have a serious impact on neighborhoods. Unmaintained lots can influence property values for surrounding homes, they can draw increased criminal activity, and they can become home to unwanted vermin and pests. The City of Durham ordinance regarding unmaintained properties is enforced by the Neighborhood Improvement Services department.
WCODEV_12.tech_notes: The number of unmaintained property violations divided by the estimated dwelling unit count, multiplied by 100. This measurement includes all unmaintained property ('weedy lot') violations, not including calls found to be not in violation or those involving commercial properties. This measurement, along with residential building code violations and abandoned, hazardous or junked vehicles reflect a City-only service and parts of Durham County are not represented by this data.
WCODEV_12.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services (2012)
WCODEV_12.links:
Durham One Call
Solid Waste Collection Services
City of Durham Weeds, Trash, and Debris Ordinances
Neighborhood Improvement Services

TREE_PCT.title: Tree Coverage
TREE_PCT.description: The percent of the selected area covered by tree canopy.
TREE_PCT.importance: The presence of trees in neighborhoods is essential for maintaining cooler temperatures (reducing the <a href='http://enviroatlas.epa.gov/enviroatlas/glossary/glossary.html#urbanheat' target='_blank'>'heat-island effect'<a/>), reducing noise, beautifying streets and parks, and even enhancing pedestrian safety. Trees also have profound environmental and health benefits, absorbing and filtering water run-off around paved areas and diluting air-borne pollutants. To learn more about the benefits of neighborhood tree coverage see this <a href='http://enviroatlas.epa.gov/EnviroAtlas_5e75e97c3d624317b428556494562451/DataFactSheets/pdf/ESC/Percenttreecover.pdf' target='_blank'>EPA fact sheet<a/>.
TREE_PCT.tech_notes: This measurement is derived from 2009-2011 National Agricultural Imagery Program one-meter digital photography for the EPA EnviroAtlas. It represents the percent of total land cover within each block group that is tree canopy, whether in forests, along streets, or individual trees.
TREE_PCT.links:
EPA EnviroAtlas
EnviroAtlas GlossaryEPA
Eco-Health Relationship Browser
Trees Across Durham

IMP_PCT.title: Impervious Area
IMP_PCT.description: The percent of the selected area covered by exposed impervious surfaces.
IMP_PCT.importance: Impervious surfaces, including paved areas such as roads, parking lots, and sidewalks as well as rooftops, prevent water from draining naturally into the ground. The results are many, including an increased burden on stormwater infrastructure, erosion, reduced water quality, <a href='http://enviroatlas.epa.gov/enviroatlas/glossary/glossary.html#urbanheat' target='_blank'>'heat island effects'<a/>, and both ground-level and water pollution. To learn more about the impacts of concentrated impervious area see this <a href='http://enviroatlas.epa.gov/EnviroAtlas_5e75e97c3d624317b428556494562451/DataFactSheets/pdf/ESC/Percenttreecover.pdf' target='_blank'>EPA fact sheet<a/>.
IMP_PCT.tech_notes: This measurement is derived from 2009-2011 National Agricultural Imagery Program one-meter digital photography for the EPA EnviroAtlas. It represents the percent of total land within each block group that is impervious and not covered by tree canopy.
IMP_PCT.links:
EPA EnviroAtlas
EnviroAtlas Glossary
Low-Impact Development Training for North Carolina
The Green Alley Handbook

PCTC30.title: Commuting 30 Minutes or More
PCTC30.description: The percentage of blockgroup residents whose commute to work takes 30 minutes or more (one-way).
PCTC30.importance: Travel time to work is an economic, environmental and quality of life metric. Economically, this reflects whether workers in a specific area are obligated to travel farther for work and that there are fewer work opportunities near their homes. Environmentally, it indicates whether a specific area contributes more vehicle miles traveled and thereby more polluting auto emissions. Finally, many commuters find longer daily trips burdensome, costly and stressful, leading to a negative impact on quality of life.
PCTC30.tech_notes:
This data includes all those commuting to the workplace, whether in personal vehicles, bicycles, walking or by public transit. As of 2010, the Durham County mean commuting time was 21.7 minutes.
As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTC30.links:
On the Map Commuting Analysis
Durham City/County Comprehensive Plan
Triangle Transit - Rideshare
American Community Survey

PCTDRALONE.title: Commuting by Driving Alone
PCTDRALONE.description: The percentage of blockgroup residents who commute to work by car or other vehicle with no other passengers.
PCTDRALONE.importance: Commuters driving alone can take advantage of cost savings from less fuel and vehicle wear, reduced roadway and parking congestion, reduced environmental impact and other benefits by participating in carpooling or rideshare opportunities.
PCTDRALONE.tech_notes: This data indicates the percentage of surveyed residents who commute by driving a personal vehicle such as a car, truck or van with no additional passengers. As with all measurements from the American Community Survey in the Neighborhood Compass, this data represents 5 years' worth of surveying. With each annual update, the 5-year period advances by dropping one year and incorporating the next. For this reason, annual releases of this measurement are not suitable for true time series comparison until no overlap exists among the survey periods.
PCTDRALONE.links:
On the Map Commuting Analysis
Durham City/County Comprehensive Plan
Triangle Transit - Rideshare
American Community Survey

ACODEV_12.title: Automotive Code Violations
ACODEV_12.description: Automotive code violations per 100 dwelling units.
ACODEV_12.importance: In addition to being unsightly, abandoned and junked vehicles can also be hazardous, whether by leaking contaminants, providing shelter for vermin and pests, or by attracting criminal activity. The City vehicle ordinance is enforced by the Neighborhood Improvement Services department.
ACODEV_12.tech_notes: The number of automotive code violations divided by the estimated dwelling unit count, multiplied by 100. This measurement includes abandoned and hazardous, as well as junked vehicle violations. It excludes calls found to be not in violation. This measurement reflects a City-only service and parts of Durham County are not represented by this data.
ACODEV_12.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services (2012)
ACODEV_12.links:
Durham One Call
City of Durham Vehicle Ordinance
Neighborhood Improvement Services

V_PER_SQMI.title: Crimes with a Violent Component
V_PER_SQMI.description: The number of crimes per square mile with a violent component that occurred in calendar year 2012.
V_PER_SQMI.importance: The violent crime rate is an indicator of basic community safety and well-being. Residents, organizations, and government alike can use this information to address high rates of violent crime where they exist and to monitor the impact of efforts to stop violent crime.
V_PER_SQMI.tech_notes: Violent crimes are commonly reported with parts 1 and 2 separate. This measurement is different, including all part 1 violent crimes and these part 2 crimes: simple assaults, certain sex offenses, child abuse and kidnapping. The number of these violent crimes occurring in each boundary is divided by the area (in square miles) of the boundary, rather than the population. This is intended to control for how crime often happens in areas that are less populated. For more detailed Durham crime reporting visit RAIDS Online.
V_PER_SQMI.source: Durham Police Department and Durham County Sheriff's Office (2012)
V_PER_SQMI.links:
RAIDS Online
Durham Crime Mapper
Durham Police Department
Durham County Office of the Sheriff
Citizens Police Academy
Partners Against Crime

P_PER_SQMI.title: Crimes Involving Property
P_PER_SQMI.description: The number of crimes per square mile involving property that occurred in calendar year 2012.
P_PER_SQMI.importance: The property crime rate is directly related to resident safety and well-being. Property crime also impacts perception of neighborhood safety and often represents a loss of or damage to private property.
P_PER_SQMI.tech_notes: Property crimes are commonly reported with parts 1 and 2 separate. This measurement is different, including all part 1 property crimes and these part 2 crimes: fraud, forgery, embezzlement, counterfeiting, stolen property and vandalism. The number of property crimes occurring in each boundary is divided by the area (in square miles) of the boundary, rather than the population. This is intended to control for how crime often happens in areas that are less populated. For more detailed Durham crime reporting visit RAIDS Online.
P_PER_SQMI.source: Durham Police Department and Durham County Sheriff's Office (2012)
P_PER_SQMI.links:
RAIDS Online
Durham Crime Mapper
Durham Police Department
Durham County Office of the Sheriff
Citizens Police Academy
Partners Against Crime

D_PER_SQMI.title: Drug-Related Crimes
D_PER_SQMI.description: The number of drug-related crimes per square mile that occurred in calendar year 2012.
D_PER_SQMI.importance: Drug crimes impact individuals, households, neighborhoods and the community as a whole. Drug crimes are often linked with other violent and property crimes, as well as with physical and mental health issues.
D_PER_SQMI.tech_notes: Drug-related crimes include all incidents involving drug and paraphernalia manufacturing, distributing, and possession charges. For more detailed Durham crime reporting visit RAIDS Online.
D_PER_SQMI.source: Durham Police Department and Durham County Sheriff's Office (2012)
D_PER_SQMI.links:
RAIDS Online
Durham Crime Mapper
Durham Police Department
Durham County Office of the Sheriff
Citizens Police Academy
Partners Against Crime
